text: so uh this is not a traditional uh conference talk so we wanted to kind of

containers in production windows what your roadmap is going to look like as well as give you an opportunity to make
asks to the community as well as you know come back and ask you guys to come and get involved
come and help us test this uh write some features or write documentation so
we're a fairly small sig compared to every other sig in the kubernetes community so
the more people that come and join us the more customer voice that we have there it's going to make it easier for us to kind of push through some of these
features and make this a reality i'm michael i worked for vmware i was
formerly at the prenda i kind of started this sig a few years ago and
took us through the journey of bringing us to where we are today and for the past couple of years patrick from
microsoft has been my co-chair and we've been working together to uh
to kind of make through on our investments in the windows ecosystem for kubernetes
so um so let's get started here like i mentioned to do a few community effort updates kind of
make you guys aware of the progress we've made and where we are today and then we'll move on to a discussion in q
a so starting in early 2016 we kind of formed the sig with a singular
effort to be around bringing windows server and windows server containers into kubernetes our goal was never to
substitute the entire control plane of kubernetes into windows but more importantly to bring windows server as a
compute node to kubernetes all of your master components are still going to run on windows but you'll be able to have
both windows as well as linux compute nodes working together for your applications
when we formed the zig aprenda and red hat were the the first contributors and we kind of took it all the way to alpha
uh in december of 16 here in seattle actually and that was basically think of this as
a proof of concept that was that was there to kind of rally the troops show what was possible and we were able to
bring a lot more folks from the community to come and join us so that we could continue towards our beta that was
a year later in december of 17 and with the beta we
had true capabilities on windows with kubernetes
so you could have storage you could have networking and we had a couple of cni plugins like ovn and ovs that were
already working and then we also had a lot more feature-rich capabilities from
the container subsystem that microsoft was providing with docker so you guys could start testing your workloads start
bringing applications into windows and making that possible to test
and then fast forward to one year later and where we are today
yeah okay there we go yeah and so so basically like over the
last year microsoft has put out two different uh what they're calling semi-annual channel releases of windows
server but that what we were doing was working with the community to find the areas where windows was lacking and we
need to do things like improve the storage and networking support and so we did that basically in concert with a few
different kubernetes releases so if you look at i think it was built either 1.9 or 1.10 we got secrets working and
then if you look at what we did with windows server 2000 or sorry 1803 and later we started to get
things like sim links working and so basically filling in a lot of those capabilities that kubernetes needed to
be able to work well we had to make changes to the os and then you got those lined up with the kubernetes releases
and so you know all those changes really kind of came together in our first long-term release which is windows
server 2019 which is what we're recommending as like the viable platform um for this stuff
going forward and um there's still more more improvements happening to work um better
with some of the different network plug-ins um like the stuff around calico and flannel um do you have that on the
next slide yeah okay yeah and so we'll talk a little bit more about that later so but
you know it's basically kind of a combined effort between you know fixing the closed source stuff and then improving the open source stuff at the
same time to make to make this work and so that's why it's it's so important that you know if you're looking at using
this in your group that you you know you meet with us in the sig meetings and you help us explain how you want to set this
stuff up and deploy it because there's so many different ways people are putting things together on linux and we
need to figure out what the right set is that's going to work best between the windows and the links environment
because you know as we already mentioned the goal is not to you know replace linux or something the goal is to have
an environment that really lets you run all your apps in one place so
in addition to that kubernetes is almost infinitely customizable right there's so many features if there's some of the
kubernetes features are more important to you you can actually raise the priority so that you can actually think
about start working on them first at a high level we're trying to enable pretty much all of the core capabilities
of kubernetes and most of them do work but there are certain features here and there that you know we just never had
the bandwidth to go and explore so having more folks that are interested in some of those features come and help us
you know will you help us we'll help you so
when the 1.13 release train was going on our initial ambition was to
go stable with 1.13 due to a variety of reasons some of it is testing stability we had to port a
lot of our testing infrastructure to to the kubernetes ci engine we just
didn't make the cut so our current plant release is with 1.14 in march of 2019.
now that's not a done deal there's still some risk in us getting ga at that release which is why we're asking you
know more folks of you guys to come and join us that way we'll make that uh increase the likelihood of that
happening so what's some of the committed work that we have so our first and foremost commitment is that you'll
be able to put windows server nodes into kubernetes and you'll be able to schedule windows server containers that is the promise
that we're making if we were going to go to ga and that's going to work well it's going to be scalable and it's going to
be reliable hyper-v isolation is still in alpha so we're strictly talking about windows
server containers if you want to use hyper-v isolated containers you have a limitation of one container per pod and
it's still in alpha so you know be aware if you're if you're trying that scenario on the networking
side flannel host gateway and vxlan will be available by that target time frame
ovn and ovs will be available as well as wind bridge and wind overlay those are kind of the
the new generation of the wind cni and where that effort has transitioned to and then you'll be able to do layer
three networking using top of rack switches so that's our committed work this is where we have members of the
siege that have committed in doing some of this work some of the work that's still under
design right now but haven't really committed resources include the group managed service accounts if you guys are
not familiar with the feature that is the ability to provide an identity for a container running on docker and windows
so that that container can access external resources like a file share or a database and have an identity that can
be authenticated and authorized against and then hybrid cluster
support that kind of has a couple of different items under it so there's the runtime
policies that we need to work on the conformance profile for windows as well as the hybrid cluster support so let me
explain a couple of these the hybrid cluster support is important because today kubernetes even though the
master components are going to run on linux the compute nodes have to be only a single operating system so the compute
nodes can either be windows only or linux only and we're working with the community to make sure that
the c-cluster life cycle and some of the other sigs are responsible for that area
that will be able to have in production a hybrid cluster where master components
are on linux and then your compute nodes are a combination of linux and windows that can accept workloads from customers
that have requirements across both operating and the systems part is runtime policies so we're
that's kind of a new thing that's coming into the kubernetes community and we're working with the team to ensure that if
you have a workload that's either windows or linux you don't need to go and put all the magic sauce inside your
pot specifications and your yaml files to kind of indicate where your workload needs to land uh there has to be some
smartness in the cluster that can identify hey this is a windows workload landing on a windows note and this is a
linux workload running on a linux docker container so
we're looking for folks from our community potentially some of you guys to come in and help us navigate this and
make sure that the right investments are made in runtime policy to to make this a reality for windows as well
so post ga and you know we mentioned 1.15 plus
there there is no real target time frame because these are so far out but some of the things that were we're going to work
on is microsoft has been putting a lot of investments around the cri and container the implementation and that's
something that we want to see light up for for windows the hybrid v isolated containers is
something that we definitely want to bring out to to stable and ga release as well and we have a ton of partners and
cus and customers are interested in both caligo and other storage and network providers and we're working with them to
to release those on kubernetes as well and the last is you know demon sets so
as you guys are familiar there's no privilege mode on windows so a lot of the demon sets are out there that kind
of require that that that i access to the host operating system so we're
working to figure out how can we enable demon sets for windows with some of the restrictions that exist in the operating
system patrick anything you want to add on on this
no i mean i think that's that's pretty much it right now in terms of the what we've been putting

basically how we're going to test and communicate windows support because it's something that's going to be

validates the quality of your kubernetes deployment overall and then they're probably going to add another profile
that says and here's windows as an additional feature so that way you can make sure that it's working well
regardless of what cloud you're going to run it on and so we're basically trying to get that right baseline of tests set

backboarding some of these uh bugs and features back into 19 no that's
not a committed thing but you know they're you know we're working with them and making sure that the long-term
service in branch of windows has all the updates that are necessary for you guys to be able to run production level workloads with flannel
okay yeah so um so for those of you that haven't tried uh deploying anything yet
on windows um one thing that i wanted to mention was um sort of a couple of the
the things around the uh the experience of actually deploying things so yesterday i had an entire session
um that that we've got a there'll be a recording available for and then i'll
probably also post some pull some of the specific demos out onto our sig windows youtube channel because i've got a
better screen recording off my laptop for that um but um
but in the labs yesterday we basically went through showing what some of the considerations are that you needed to make as you're doing deployments
and so you know today if um whenever you've got things set up you're always going to have a mix of windows
and linux nodes so even if you're only using the linux node for like the leader roles like where you're going to run
your api server scheduler and all and all those typical
pods there you're still going to have the windows nodes there that are running there and
so when you're deploying stuff today you want to be sure to use node selectors which let you pick what
operating system a deployment's going to going to run on because if you try to deploy something like you know your
ingress controller using nginx which is using a linux container and it
inadvertently gets scheduled on a windows node well that's not going to work and vice versa if you've got the
windows app trying to run on a linux node and so you know the scheduler and kubernetes api already has this
capability called node selectors and taints that you can use to control where things are going to land
so at a minimum you want to be using the node selectors on there and if you're going to
experiment with adding just a few windows nodes to an existing environment you may also want to set a taint on
those nodes as well because that way if you've got existing deployments that are already there in the cluster that might
you know go from one node to another as things fail over the taint would prevent the linux applications from accidentally
showing up on the windows node but the tank can can prevent that and then so when you go and deploy your
windows application you just put a node selector and a toleration in there and then it will still run on windows just
fine but that's a way that you can you know sort of segment the workloads out and make sure they run on the right os
funny enough uh robert from ticketmaster is here they were the first ones to kind of flag that out as an issue uh way back
when so uh it works now a little bit differently but it does work yeah
and and so you know we're looking for for thoughts on ways and how we might be able to improve that um yeah one of the
one of the possible ways to do it would be to use an admission controller that looked that basically
analyzed what the image was and then base added these for you and so i think that's something that's
technically feasible but the trade-off there would be if you're doing a whole lot of small deployments now you've got a whole lot
of load over on this controller that's going to have to make calls over the network over to your container registry
to find out is this a windows or linux image there and so
these are the sorts of things where it's like if this is you know something that you want to help with you know we would we would love to have um any help that's
there because that's not a windows development project that's just requires some fluency you know in the kubernetes
apis and that application that emission controller you know could run on the existing linux nodes today
so a couple other things are i know that i've seen some templates that people have used on linux have
really low memory limits of via like one or two hundred megs that's not going to work on windows just to start a
container you're going to need at least 300 and it's not that 300 megs are going to all be in active use
it's that the windows services if if they need to allocate that memory they
need to be able to go up to there and if you set a limit too low things will just start crashing
and so in the examples that i pasted that got from my session i had relatively low
um requests of like one or two hundred megs but i was raising the limits up to you know the 600 to 800 meg meg range to
make sure that the applications could run and you know that's not memory that's all arcade up front it's
just if the application needs it it can it can use it so the resource constraints still work you just need to
raise them up a bit because of the windows background services running in those containers
then the last thing is historically windows implemented a lot of the apis that people could call from
user mode in kernel mode and that is very different from linux because
in linux you know if there's one thing that lance torvalds did right is he stabilized the
syscall interface very very early and fought off anybody that wanted to change those
and what and that's given you you the benefit of well you know most applications
aren't going to crash if you change your kernel version but unfortunately nobody on the
in in the windows team had had had designed that early on and so
the user mode applications need to be able to run on the same kernel that they were built on so if you build your
container on a windows server 2019 machine it needs to run on a windows server 2019 machine
and if you're using an older version like 1709 or 1803 the same the same is
true and so that's why the hyper-v isolation is going to be so important for us to finish because that's going to allow you
to update your windows notes first but then it will just bring up the kernel for the container that needs it at that
older version so that's going to give you that backwards compatibility so you can move the windows notes forward even
if your apps haven't been rebuilt in containers yet basically until that happens if you guys
do have a need to run multiple versions of the os you know obviously what we recommend and what microsoft is
recommending is windows server 2019 should be both your container host as well as your images as one of the most
stable platform it's the most feature reach and that's the one that we're going to go ga with but if you have
other needs then the taints and tolerations that patrick mentioned earlier is the best way to match the os
image of the host to the os image of your containers that way they land to the right spot

going to say the command's going to be docker pull mcr.microsoft.com
and so that particular service is replicated in more regions than docker hub was
initially and it's also going to be available in some of the sovereign clouds so
if you're like in the china market and you're using azure there that's going to be available there as well and so one of
the things we've been trying to do is focus on improving the cdn to get some of those download speeds because i've
seen people that were in you know latin america downloading from the us east coast server and that did not go well
so you know fixing the infrastructure is one thing that we've done to improve the speed there the other thing we've done
is if you look at version by version we've been chopping down the size of those images
pretty considerably if you look at the windows server 2016 and like extract it with tar there were
actually duplicate files in there and that was because the way that the file system layout worked it couldn't do sim
links on the fly as it was extracting it we fixed that in half the image size in
windows server i think it was 1709 or 1803 and then we trimmed out even more files
that were not needed for server um 2019 and so i think the

hyper-v isolation and using kubernetes to orchestrate all that i mean i think it's something that
that would be technically possible but we would need to be

is designed where you know each node can run only one thing and
you know so the common idea of like well you know can this node run both you know amd 64 and arm 64 code like technically
somebody could do that today with qmu but it's not something that the scheduler is designed to do and so
running multiple os's on the same host is something where it's like even though the container run times underneath may
be able to do it we would need to work very closely across a lot of groups like sig architecture and sig node to figure
out you know how you would want to enable that scenario just because it's not something that
